title: 8mm Y axis conversion for Flyingbear P902 3D printer

description.text:
I made these corner mounts for 688ZZ miniature ball bearings in order to make a more solid Y axis with 8mm shafts. I had a lot of problems with bent shafts when I had the original 6mm ones, I tried purchasing others from 2 different places and I only got bent ones. This mount loses about 8mm from print height but I am OK with that. I changed the stepper motor with 4.2Kgf up from the original 2.2Kgf and I purchased the following parts:

4x ball bearings 688ZZ from ebay any seller (not flanged)
5x 20 teeth GT2 timing pulleys with 8mm ID
4x 5mm plastic spacer 8mm ID, 14mm OD (or you can print them)
2x 8mm steel shaft with 390mm length.
12x M2.6 stainless steel pan head philips self tapping screw for plastic, 5mm length

One ball bearing goes into each mount, the cover is placed and three screws hold the cover into place. They should fit snugly into the corner.

Printer:

Flyingbear P902

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50

Notes:

Print them as they are in the STL, laying flat, no supports are needed and it is the best strength.
When you print these, make sure it is in ABS and that you print a calibration test cube before, then adjust XYZ sizes according to the percentage the cube is left after shrinking when cold or if you have steps/mm differences i.e. my settings for ABS are X=100.6%, Y=102.6 and Z=99%. If you do that, the bearings should fit with a little push without issues.

Why ABS and not PLA? Cause otherwise if you decide to build an enclosure and heat goes over 60 degrees inside, the things will melt and your Y axis will be out of alignment. Or like the guy who had PLA 3D printed parts for his 3D printer and he left the thing in the car, on a sunny day, then he collected a pile of junk.

author: bailey123123

description.text:
My design of an 8 leaf (double layer) iris box. It uses a linked mechanism, inspired by those expanding sphere toys, which allows it to open to a large diameter.

I have many other box designs which you can find on my MyMiniFactory profile: https://www.myminifactory.com/users/Brien%20Allison

The box is 80mm overall in diameter, while the container opening is around 62mm. It is opened by pushing the notches in the top of the box in an anti-clockwise direction.

No supports are required for this object.

The hinges of the mechanism use ridged pins and holes that clip together. The effectiveness of these hinges may depend on your specific printer and print settings (I find the hinges are looser with higher print speeds for some reason). The tolerance on the hinges is 0.15mm which works for me. I could add parts with different tolerances if you require.

I would recommend printing one upper and lower door with the settings you expect to print the whole model to test them. The hinges on the points of the doors are slightly smaller than the others so don't mix them up when testing them. Some of the hinge sections are quite thin as I focused on compactness, but are suitably strong on my models, using good quality PLA.

'top door 1' is a plain iris leaf for the top of the box while 'top door 2' is an iris leaf with a notch cut out of it for opening the box. I recommend you print at least two of 'top door 2' and arrange them on opposite sides of the box to allow ease of opening. You may add more if you wish e.g. four in the first printed example or all eight in the second. You will also need to print 8x 'lower door', 8x 'link' and 1x 'container'.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm layer height

You may need to scrape off excess plastic around the base layer after printing, in order for the parts to fit together snugly.
You will probably need some pliers or similar to clip the hinges together.
While assembling the mechanism I recommend you first build small sections e.g. a quarter of the iris, and move the hinges a bit to loosen them up. It's ideal if the iris is assembled in the partly open position, otherwise it can be very hard to close if assembled in the fully open position and the hinges are still stiff. Then attach the links to the container (this may require a fair amount of force depending on tolerances) and finally the links to the lower iris doors.

comments.text: what layer height do you recommend for the container
comments.author: shynka

comments.text: 0.1mm layer height, at least for the top section where the holes in the box are as that should make sure the hinges work ok.

title: Stepper Motor Mount for Celestron C11 Autofocuser

description.text: This mount allows you to attach a NEMA 17 stepper motor with planetary gearbox to a CPC1100 or EDGE HD 1100 focus dial. There is also an insert that must be lightly press-fit into the brass focuser barrel. This is excluded so that you can fine-tune it for your motor and print. This allows you to use Robert Brown's MyFocuser on SourceForge. This can be useful for controlling focus in observatories, at educational events (so that nobody touches the focus) or anything else. Focus is critical for planetary viewing/imaging. Touching the scope while focusing will always result in less accurate focus due to mechanical vibrations. With the software Robert provides, you can integrate it into astronomy software or use his.

comments.text:
After printing these and installing along with the 50mm fans ( https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B071WMHNG5 ) I did not use them for the following reasons.
1- the fan s themselves stick out over the effector by a fair amount. The result of this is that it can and will hit the x an y belts on a large build ( x-y wise ). So effectively, they will limit the build size.
2- The position of the duct exit was more toward the heat block and not the nozzle, i.e they point more toward the from near the extruder fan then the rear where the nozzle is.
3- They are also too high and blow on the heater block.

description.text:
There's one thing that I've had issues and hatred for since I started printing...
Filament care and storage...

A while back I picked up some fairly well known higher price filament but almost from the start I had nothing but blockage issues, I always store my spools in ziplock bags with desicant and try to keep it clean, but turns out there was a lot of dust/particles on the filament, so I went looking for a filter, found a couple, they worked, but there were issues...

There was the style which clipped on the top of the hotend, it worked, but made filament changes a ... not so much fun...

Then there is the inline style I tried and liked (like sneakypoo's which this is based around), but sitting on the hotend they rattled, sitting on my filament guide they rattled...

Also, every time I went to change filament i had to take the filter off, clip the filament, get the new one, load it...
carp...
unload it, work it through the filter, then the guide, reload it...
and on...

There must be a better way!
and I think there is... that's why I made this...
Its:

  • a filament filter, made to be added without unloading the filament.
  • a clip to help store your filament without kinking it or trying it,
  • a guide, and rounded to fit into my (and most) guides, and gives just a little tension to keep the filament from occasionally moving back on a move and falling off the side of the reel. (ok, that's a little lame, but I needed a 3rd for the 3-In-1...)
  • a filament oiler (for you that want to use oil) just add a couple drops of mineral oil to the sponge. I've read this can help with Bowden tube designs to reduce friction, I'm not at that point yet so I can't comment either way.

One of the pictures is of a filter after ~10 hours of printing, even storing all my filaments in descant bags whenever they're not in use you can see the dirt/dust accumulated in it even from clean filament.

Let me know what you think, comments always appreciated!

Still to do... cleanup my filament frame guide and add it, there are many others out there, as long as it has a hole for filament to go through this filter should work with it fine.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used 100% infill just so the clip portion was solid, I had a couple ealier designs fail after some time as the clip cracked.

Build & Assembly Notes:
  • Designed to be printed as one piece, when you pop it off the bed it the hinge should swing freely, if it doesn't or is too tight you might need to slow the print or increase your fan speed.
  1. Print the thing.
  2. cut a small piece of non particulating sponge to fit, it should be roughly the same base size and twice as high as would fill the hollow core. I found that my wife's makeup sponges worked the best (although don't tell her I've been stealing them) sponge from a kitchen scrubber works just as well.
  3. cut a slot ~1/2 way down through the sponge.
  4. Insert filament, flip closed (you might have to coax the sponge into place a little)...
  5. Winning!

To store filament:

  1. unload the filament from your printer,
  2. pull it to the side a little to pop it out of the centre and into the storage cut,
  3. Clip it to the side of the reel...
  4. Winning!
Revisioning:

v1.0 - initial release.

To complete this thing you will need:

1x the part
1x a small block of foam
1x a filament spool you need to store...

comments.text:
I gave a like because of the design (clip closure, hinge, double function ... one big step above what is found here).
Regarding the functionality, I choose a different approach, have the spool on the side, not attached to the printer, its axis aligned with the Y axis so the filament makes a loop up in the X Z plane going through a 4mm PTFE tube that will rub it without much friction, the dust falling off naturally. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2318909
OK, my filament is not that dusty and may be it wouldn't be as effective for a really dusty one.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Thanks!
I agree the spool shouldn't be attached to the printer, just haven't advanced my build to that point yet, its a WIP lol.
Once I do (likely a cabinet for noise/dust control) I'll likely use a PTFE delivery tube arrangement of some sort, and from many things I've read friction loss can be mitigated with a light filament oiling, I'm not so sure I want to add an oil to the mix in the hotend but this design could be used for that as well.
It also helps with filament handling; I've had a couple of harder filaments when I unloaded them (or pulled them out of their bags) wanted to uncoil and tangle, having a weight/mass/handle on the end of the filament all the time helps.
its also nice to always have the clip on the filament, then I'm never walking around or searching for one while carrying a spool of filament that I just unloaded, they have a way of disappearing at the worst of times...
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
The spool attached to the frame will transmit its vibration when jerked by the extruder (mine is on the X carriage) Furthemore, with the Prusa I found that with the spool axis // to the Y axis, the filament makes a natural loop, needs only one guide at the top (can be partially seen on the picture) No filament bending, no need for oiling, it easily follows the carriage movement and retraction.
A piece of PTFE tube (flared ) on the extruder also helps.

title: Octahedron Bevel Gear Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I claim this to be the world's first hand held fidget spinner with bevel gears!
This toy can be:

  • rolled around on your palm.
  • held on two corners on the center-hub and watch all 8 gears spin in synchronization.
  • held on two opposite-face gears and watch the middle 6 gears revolve.
  • and maybe discover more ways to play.

For mathematically / geometrically oriented audiences: The toy comprises of 8 bevel gears arranged as a surface of an octahedron. The center hub is a truncated octahedron.

Note: this is not meant to be a high RPM or a long spin time fidget spinner. This toy is an object to enjoy the mechanical motion of the gears. Print, assemble, and have fun!

Things to Print:

  • 1x CenterHub.stl
  • 8x BevelGear.stl
  • 8x Sleeve.stl

Thing to Purchase:

  • 8x 625 Ball Bearing (ID = 5mm, OD = 16mm, T =5mm)
  • 8x M3x20 Flathead/Countersunk bolts
  • 8x M3 Nuts
  • 24x M3 Washers

To Assemble:

  1. Assemble total of 8 Gear Sub-Assemblies. Follow the images for details. The sleeve is inserted inside the inner diameter of the bearing- the sleeve is there to keep the bearing and gear aligned. The two layer M3 washer is there to provide 1mm spacing between the bearing and the gear. (Washers and sleeve can be substituted with other things, if you find a better part).
  2. Insert the ball bearing end of the Gear Sub-Assembly into the hole of center hub. The hub is designed so the bearing is friction fit. A file or glue may be needed depending on your 3D printer.
    Simple assembly video is available here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H_NhFbz7sxU.

Tip:
I found that the bearings spin better if degreased. I used ethanol, but other degreasing agents (IPA, acetone, etc) may be used.

description.text:
Here are several versions of Mr. Meeseeks from Rick and Morty show!

Originals for resin printers made by 3dprintguy (http://www.3dprintguy.co/). conversion to FDM printers and base added here: https://www.stlfinder.com/model/mr-meeseeks-new-old-rick-and-morty-8wW1AOKe/7462224

These files had multiple errors, several shells, internal structures and errors, and were too skinny for my printer. I fixed all errors and made watertight, solid, and thicker arms and legs. Also, I mixed it up a bit, and modified the arms and made mirror images to come up with several versions and to have a more complete assortment of Mr. Meeseeks. Much simpler to print.

Please post a photo to share if you print this, and check out my other scans of skulls and bones at http://www.thingiverse.com/dricketts/designs.
Be sure to "Like" my Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/FetalReproductions to subscribe to my current prints/blogs, and see my Etsy page at http://Etsy.com/FetalReproductions for baby fetal scans, skulls, and other items to own.

title: Hard drive and SSD caddy for HP Z600 Z620 Z800 XW6600 XW8600

description.text:
This is a caddy for HP workstations Z600, Z620, Z800, XW6600, XW8600 or anything that has at least 2x5.25 spaces open. The caddy can be secured with the built-in latch, but it is a tight enough fit to secure itself by friction alone.

It can house 2x3.5+3x2.5 drives. 2 of the 2.5 drives can be SSD or HDD with 7-13.5mm thickness. The 3rd one will fit a 7mm SSD only.

+++++++++++++

I uploaded a raid version that will allow you to use additional 2.5 drives instead of the 3.5 ones or in any valid combination (9 x 2.5 drives or 5 x 2.5 drives + 2 x 3.5). If you don't use 3.5 drives at all, you have to use the 1-inch spacers to keep the original dimensions. You can get commercial brass M3 spacers or use 8xM3 nuts. I included a design here too that you can print as many times as needed. Use 30mm M3 screws inside the spacers.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15-25%

Notes:

The tolerances are wide so it can be printed on semi accurate printers as well, but as a consequence, the M3 nuts need to be glued in with epoxy. They won't pop in and stay in by themselves,

Needs 6x M3x35mm + 8x M3x25mm
Also, use an 80mm fan + fan grill +4 self-threading screws.
I did not use washers. The design is solid without them.

Problem with hotend's temperature on Anycubic I3 ?
Looking for an efficient cable-holder ?

Easy to print.
One part.

I3 mega is a very good printer, but sometimes hotend's temperature is instable. The problem is the plug on the top of the hotend : plug is easily disconnected when printing.

I saw temperature increase at 560°C !!!!

There are some "things" who try to solve the problem, but they aren't enough strong :

SOLUTION :

My cable holder is STRONG and Easy to print.
ABS is better but you can print it in PLA.

ASSEMBLY :

Disconnect the small plug (not the taller), unscrew 4 bolts, place the cable-holder. Reassemble.
That's it.

title: Thermaltake Core V21 foot cover / extension

description.text:
A simple foot extension thing for the Thermaltake Core V21 computer case.
I made it because the desk I use has a place to set your computer just above the floor. The problem is that my Core V21 overhangs the platform, making it tilt onto the carpet.

So I measured the foot nub of the case, and cut a cylinder out of a cube to use as a way to prop up the overhang.

It works just perfectly :)
All you'd need to go for yourself is change the height of the model to accommodate your situation.

Anet A8

I used .2

It doesn't need to hold up a bunch of weight anyways, so it worked just fine.
I think I used 2 shells.. possibly 3.

description.text:
I created this for my son who has tiny hands (he's 3!) and couldn't spin the usual spinners.

This is using the smaller bearing type called "MR105ZZ".

I made this with pretty tight tolerances. I've only printed this in a no name glow-in-the-dark PLA and I had to use the blunt end of a screw driver to drift it in - not much force was required.

The axles I copied from "idnarbjm" and resized it to fit the smaller bearing type. I then used a dot of super-glue to keep them together more permanently.
Original design for axle seen here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1848330

Thanks and enjoy
Jerry

title: Solar Eclipse Canon EF 70-300 with 67mm lens thread filter holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a hood for a Canon EF 70-300 with 67mm lens thread for solar eclipses. You have to apply the AstroSolar film yourself

Use double sided sticky tape on the (square) top of the "solar-lenscap-bottom.stl" thing. stick the BAADER AstroSolar Safety film on top of the double sided sticky tape. and snap on the "solar-lenscap-top"

Then hang it inside the ring of your lens. It should fit snugly and not immediatly fall out. IF this is not the case. Consider using double sided sticky tape on the edges of the ring to keep it in place or if it is slightly too big, just heat the bottom up with a heat gun or hairdryer

I wanted to share it because someone asked for it.

Source for the film:
http://www.robtics.nl/product_info.php?products_id=1339

author: someoneonly

description.text:
I've seen several filament guides on here, but almost all of them require removing the filament and running it through a loop, or seem like the filament would come out of it easily. I decided to design one that you can install without having to remove the filament or deal with any of that mess. All you need is an M4x8 bolt and a T-Slot Nut to install.

I have printed this already and it came out looking great, but the version I printed had an upper slot guide that got a little wonky, so I modified it to hopefully print easier. I have not yet tried this new design, but I'm sure it will be fine.

Hope this is useful to you!
This is for a Prusa 3D Printer, but since it is parametric, it can be used for whatever.

Requires:
2x M3x10 Screws
2x M3 Nuts
2x M3 Washers
FIXED: When tightening you now don't have to worry about the plastic Breaking.
Cut out the support on the gap in the middle of the coupling before tightening.

what to do after 3d printing

how i designed this

i used a caliper to measure the hop up chambre front dimensions and recreated it in autodesk inventor.
then i copy-pasted the dimension i needed from the hop up to the clip design and extruded it.
lastly i modified the inner dimension so that the barrel would remain stable and 3d printed it several time until i got the dimensions right.
material used i used pla but you may use whatever rigid filament you have

author: airsoft3D

description.text: This is just a simple spool hanger bracket to suit 25mm (1") hanger shaft .There was a similar one that i downloaded a while back , but it was too thin & recently broke. Quickly designed this beefed up version . Re-scale the Z axis in your slicer if you want to thin it down a bit . Currently carrying 7 x 1kg spools with no issues.

I was looking a various fidgets and found one that is typically made out of chain links and key ring rings.
I couldn't find anyone had designed on to print so thought I would give it a crack. Quite pleased it worked first iteration.
It is quite strong as the rings are printed in a long cross section.
I have also included the gcode that worked for me on both my Original Prusa i3 MII and my CR10. Both PLA. The Prusa is at .08 layer height and takes about 2hrs to print.
The CR 10 gcode is .15 layer height and takes about 1 hour, only uses 20 cents plastic.
Here is a link to how they work https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0Zt1AdacyJM

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

25

Notes:

This does require full support, but only takes between 1-2 hour printing I've prined at .08 and .15 layers and both work well.
Needs a little bit of sanding/scraping on the bottom where the support was but works well.
A bit novel, not as good as a fidget cube however, but interesting how it rotates and the rings pass each other.

These parts are for the I3 Rework by eMotion Tech. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119616 UPDATE 4-9-2015:
I added all my other improvents that I have designed since I uploaded the first 2. I liked the look of their design. But after putting it together there were 2 things I wanted to improve. First. My stepper motors were a bit on the big end of the tolerated size (42.3mm wide) This caused an alignment error in the z axis of the M5 threaded rod and the x ends. I increased the room around the motor. Also I added a ridge to align the motor mount with the frame. Second. I really liked the idea by ffleurey to protect the z-axis smooth rods against the x belt tension. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:160636 Update 12-3-2014 :
3 Upgraded the Y tensioner for 624zz bearings. It is retrofittable without removing any threaded bars.Just cut off the old tensioner.
4 Made a few modifications to the x idler tensioner to prevent alignment problems. UPDATE 4-9-2015
5: I designed and tested a pulley with barreled shape for the belts. It centers the belt automatically so it does not rub the sides of the pulley. 6: I designed a holder to mount the original Rework extruder as a bowden extruder. 7: I added braces to the frame. They can be assembled without modifiing the original parts. 8 I added brackets to mount the megatronics V2 box 9 I replaced M5 nuts in x axis ends by long M5 connector nuts to smooth possible errors in M5 thread. 10 I placed the whole printer in a IKEA STUVA cupboard. Works perfectly for ABS printing in "heated"chamber.
http://www.ikea.com/nl/nl/catalog/products/S69873735/ I designed the parts in Freecad. http://www.freecadweb.org/

All parts are printable without supports. Use "brim" to keep them flat except on the pulley halves. The holder for the x pulley accepts either 2 624bearings clamped together or 1 624 bearing with 2 pulley halves glued to it and 2 bushings. To mount the bottom brace: remove the rear top M10 nuts and replace it with an M10 connector nut of +/-30mm long. This way you do not have to dissasemble and replace the M10 rod. that holds your motor. Some other parts I used to improve my I3 are:

comments.author: djvdpant

comments.text: When I had my first printer (Printrbot Simple) it came with spectra. For my Y steps i had to use this formula (wanted_length/measured_length)*old y steps. To use this formula you tell the printer to move the y axis some value, that value is wanted_length, after the printer moves you measure the distance it has covered, this value is measured_length.  The rest should be straightforward but I dreaded the spectra on my previous printer. Hope you can get everything worked out

comments.author: roontoon

comments.text: Why do you need two screws with nuts near the smooth rods of x-axis?
comments.author: tse

comments.text:
Hi Tse,
Good question. If you leave out the screws and tighten the x-belt very thight. You will squeeze the x-axis brackets together. This will bend the z-axis smooth rods. The screws lean on the X axis smooth rods. They make sure the belt force is deflected through the smooth x rods to the left x bracket. The right bracket can "move" independently and does not bear the load in x direction. So the z axis is also not loaded from the side and doesn't bend.
Does this answer your question?
Happy printing!
Diederik

title: CR-10 Z-Axis Stepper Spacer

description.text:
I realized that my Z-Axis Stepper is not perfectly aligned with the threaded rod. This puts unnecessary stress and force on the Z-Axis Coupler. To get it aligned with the threaded rod I designed this simple 1mm spacer which is installed inbetween the stock mount for the stepper motor and the frame.
When they are perfectly aligned you can use a non-flexible coupler like me.

UPDATE:
I added an 1.5mm and 2mm spacer too. For me 1mm was perfect. Since it is a very fast print just try it out!

CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

The better the alignment the lesser stress you put on your coupler and maybe you even get better prints, because the leadscrew doesn't get that much force.

description.text:
Move your printer display to where you want it

With this modification, you can place the control box wherever you want and still have access to the display and control button.
Remove display

Open the control box, remove the current display cable and the display. Put the new longer cable in place in the control box, pull the cable through the hole in the control box where the display were.
There is an stl attach to print a cover plate that fits where the display was in the control box.

Print

I printed this in PETG, but any hard filament should do.

Assembly

I have a Wanhao i3 v2. I'm not sure if Wanhao has used the same display on all subsequent models. I suggest you print the back plate first and check if it the holes and the connector on the display circuit board aligns with the plate. If it does, I believe you are good.
The stand (feet parts) are optional.

Ideas for the future

One idea I have is to attach a magnet on the back plate and another where I want to have it mounted. This way it's easy to take it down and use it "hand held" and then put it back on the magnet when finished fiddling with it.

description.text:
User taurelis asked if I could design a QX 105 frame so I thought I'd give it a shot. This is what I came up with. I have not moved the electronics from my carbon fiber frame, but I have made sure the motors fit and the props will clear. You will need to transfer the camera mount and top plate and, I imagine, do a little sanding to get everything to fit. I designed a hole at the bottom of the motor mounts to secure the motors with a servo screw. You may not need this depending on your printer. I have not flown this so cannot vouch for the strength or weight. Let me know if you try it.
UPDATE: I got some feedback from Taurelis and have pushed out the nose a bit and added posts to hold the battery and a bracket for the LEDs. Have also created a prop guard.
UPDATE #2 8-14-17: Had an incorrect measurement - this is corrected file (I hope!)
Update 8-15-17: Taurelis reported that the frame was too heavy. Latest version has about 5 grams removed. Not sure if this will work, but I suggest also removing the LED bar to minimize weight.

title: Terraforming Mars board game - Storage Solution

description.text:
Storage solution for Terraforming Mars board game.

** UPDATE: 7 Sep 2017: Sleeved Card Support
I'm personally not use card sleeve but I understand that many of you will need it.

Now the storage solution is sleeved card support. You need to print the file TM_Card_Sleeve.stl instead of TM_Card. No need to print TM_Card_Fill.stl and TM_Inner_One.stl. You might need to print file TM_Inner_Wall.stl to put inside the big box. Keep some card like corporate card in the big box. The rest goes to TM_Card_Sleeve.

You need to print 1 copy of every STL file except the S-box that you need to print it for 3-5 copies as you need. Details of insert setting are below.

S-Box is for store player cubes seperately. Actually it need 5 copies of box and lid. They will fill up the game box perfectly.
But in case you also need to have some card holder. You may print it only 3 sets of S-Box and lids and use the Inner_One and Two for store 2 remaining player cube sets.
Twelve of my card holders are perfectly replace those couple S-boxes as my picture show you (Download it here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2446046).

For people who store game box vertically. You will need some foam core or thick card board to fill up the box for boxes lid will not acidentally open. Or you could use cylinder magnet size of 3mm diameter x 3.75mm height to make them stick together.

B-Ramp is not required but if you play solo a lot you can print it and insert it in the inner slot inside the Big Box. You can use the small slot in the big box to store your player cubes. The B-Ramp will help you to easier pick up those cubes.

This is an enclosure for a GRBL cnc controller keyboard I specifically designed for my homemade CNC machine. If you plug this into a computer running bCNC, it appears as a 'standard' keyboard but its not. To move each axis on your machine (two buttons for each axis) you push the according buttons (Z-Axis on the right side).
There is also a rotary encoder and a OLED display to set the step distance for each push of a button. So if you push the X+ button, it sends multiple keystrokes to the computer (bCNC) initiating the grbl controller to move the set amount of mm on the x-axis.

Because I sometimes accidently pushed one of the buttons when working on the CNC, I added a enable button (red little button) at the top. So I have to push the red button and one of the other buttons to actually move a axis...

title: 4010 long fan duct for E3D V6 Clone

description.text:
I made this duct for four reasons:
1) The fan that came with the hot end was loud
2) A replacement 2010 fan is way more expensive than a 4010 fan
3) The existing fan duct and fan housing broke when installing so it rattled even more.
4) I needed a longer tunnel given my X-Carriage setup

This duct is made for a clone hot end. Specifically, a Dophee E3D V6 3D Printer J-head Hotend Bowden Extruder for 1.75mm 0.4mm Filament:

https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/B01M8QCKQF/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The duct fits nice and snug, but I provided an opening for a zip tie in case you want to cinch it down.

I've included a measurement drawing so you can see if it will fit on your set up before printing.

Enjoy.

It didn't scan with the MakerBot scanner well at all - really, really poor!  So, it's still on the to-do list.  I really ought to give it a try with my still untried Sense 3D scanner, as well as some of the other pieces for an idea of how much better (or worse) they would come out.  One thing I have almost completed is a change to what I've scanned so far that hollows them out and adds a screw-in stopper at the bottom so that lead shot or sand can fill them, making them feel more substantial - at least, that's my theory!  So, stay tuned for a future scan of the pawn and maybe more (still hoping I'm OK relative to the museum re my scans).

description.text:
This was at first just an exercise to learn FreeCAD design using formulas and parameters to design objects and turned out to be more. The basic shape and proportions of the Ugrinsky rotor is based on this image.

Since I already had designed the blades based on this, why not actually test it in the real world? So here it is, it uses a NEMA 11 stepper motor as generator. There are two 6000Z bearings and a aluminium tube with 10mm diameter.

The timing belt I used is a T2.5-177.5 width 6mm like this

I tested it and it runs pretty well without a load on the generator, I still have to test it with a charger connected. I think scaling it up to twice the size would work really well with the NEMA 11 stepper generator, but I would have to print the blades in parts and then assembly them.

You can watch the system running on youtube

comments.text: The bearing is a 6000Z (info is in the description too), 26mm outer diameter and 10mm inner diameter,  but any other bearing with these dimensions should work. Its an encapsulated version (probably not the best in therms of low friction). I uploaded the missing pulleys stl files.

title: Balancing kit for Zenmuse X5 camera and Panasonic Lumix 35-100mm Zoom Lens

description.text:
Although the Panasonic Lumix G 35-100mm zoom lens is on the list of DJI compatible lenses for the Zenmuse X5 camera and gimbal, it is a major problem to balance making it difficult to use. It is a very useful manual zoom lens that is relatively inexpensive and produces excellent images and and very useable video imagery.

This balancing kit is a neat and simple way to easy balance the X5 camera, gimbal and lens that allows the balance to be easily and quickly changed when the zoom settings it changed.

The kit consists of a 3D printed rear carrier and holder to balance tilt and a side carrier and holder to balance roll.

Just add lead or other weight to the carriers and hold in place with Blu Tack or similar. You can quickly adjust the weight in each carrier as required.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=skUjRuFQolw

Print with 100% infill so the thin walls are correctly formed. These can be printed in ABS, PLA or PETG with settings appropriate to your printer.

Made some minor modifications. I was finding that inserting the Jack was tight. So I have modified it to be another 2mm shorter in height and 5mm shorter in length.

Voila! No bed sag! My CR-10's build plate had sag in the middle. Just enough to throw off my bed leveling process.

I love the Jailcee W-Jack design but I needed a few modifications.

  1. Now uses M3 screw and nuts
  2. Total height of the jack reduced by 1.5mm
  3. Built in tracks for less possibility of side slip.

comments.text: Dumb question, but what are these used for?
comments.author: chunkyjo

comments.text: Not a dumb question at all! On some CR-10's the build plate can sag in the center and edge. This wedge helps push the bed back in to a more proper position from the center. makes it more level overall.
comments.author: chunkyjo

comments.text:
FYI, this doesn't work on the new CR-10S with the factory insulated bed. It's too high by several mm. Besides, the bed insulation is spongy, preventing a solid purchase and hides the wiring, making safe placement nearly impossible.
Nice idea for older machines, though. I wish it had some way of keeping itself from falling apart when not under tension...
comments.author: Elmojo

comments.text: Thanks for fixing this to use sane bolt/nut sizes.
comments.author: corwin7

comments.text: Way too small. Doesn't reach the bed by about a quarter inch. Also, there's no real way to tighten it once it's underneath, and you can't put it in the center of the bed anyway because of the thermistor. This seemed like a good idea until I actually put it together.
comments.author: DonStauffer

comments.text: I ended up scaling the model up to 4/3 of its original size in Cura (4/3 so that I can use a 4mm screw and nuts), and it fits perfectly now.
comments.author: DonStauffer

comments.text: interesting, I had the opposite problem, see above.
comments.author: DonStauffer

comments.text: It depends on what you have on top of your print bed. This thing is probably designed with the original glass plate in mind. I have replaced the glass plate with a fiber glass one. Since the fiber glass plate is thinner, I have to move the bed up, increasing the distance between the base and the bed. The proper size for the wedge depends on the thickness of what ever you have on top of your print bed. It would be great if this could be made parametric :)
comments.author: Elmojo

comments.text:
I see your point, but that's not my issue. I have a mirror tile on my bed, which is about 2/3 the thickness of the stock glass plate. Assuming the jack is designed for the stock glass, if anything, it should be a little loose on my machine, and yours for that matter.
As it is, the issue seems to be that the newest versions of the CR-10S are a bit different than the older CR-10, as noted in my original comment at the top.
comments.author: aspectoid

comments.text: Sorry, I actually meant to reply to DonStauffer's comment. I understand that your issue is the bottom insulation. I'm afraid there's not much you can do if you want to tackle the sagging issue except removing the insulation. My print bed came without the insulation, and I do not really miss it. I have never measured the time it takes to heat the bed up, but it's only a couple of minutes. Once it's heated up, temperature remains stable. Maybe that would be an option?

description.text:
Hey friends! I really like iClints M4 Rifle, but I wanted to make it look a little more modern. So, I took the handguard part of the rifle and I extracted the inside section (I believe that it is the barrel and the gas blowback, correct me if I am wrong) and added a quad picatinny rail system with "racetrack" ovals in between. Hope that you enjoy.

Credit to iClint for the connection points between the receiver, handguard and the barrel, as well as barrel and gas blowback tubes. You can find the full gun here: (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2370157)

If you do decide to print this, please share how the print went. My printer is still backordered from Prusa so when I get the printer up and running, I will update the print settings.

Still a work in progress, but here is the Tinkercad link if you want to go crazy with it.
https://tinkercad.com/things/hD1dLp8FuVz

Update: V2
Accentuated the end of the picatinny rails to look more accurate to a modern M4 handguard. Previous versions will remain uploaded unless an update is to objectively better the version, such as correcting dimensions, shapes, etc.

V3 will probably be a sliced version of 2 that uses a similar 1.75 mm pins to align the two halves like the receiver and other part of iClint's rifle.

Notes:

I do not know the best way to print this, but 2 ways that I would recommend are:
1.) Printing it on its side like a soda can.
2) Slicing it in half and gluing them together like the receiver.

The picatinny rails will be hard for the printer in 1, but 2 will also be a complete pain to glue together.

comments.text: Great work mate. I planned to do the same and eventually release the entire SOPMOD kit to make what people Know today as the modern AR15.

author: xdelucax

description.text:
Depending on assembly, the doll can be made to be very loose and more of a ragdoll or more of a posable figurine once assembled.

Needed for assembly:

  • Glue (preferably some kind of super glue)
  • About 100mm of 1.75mm PLA filament to use as rivets.
  • Something to heat up PLA, lighter or soldering iron works fine.
  • Sandpaper

This print is in 36 parts to ensure that it can be printed on pretty much any type and/or size of printer.
The two .stl files you see here are mostly for reference but Posable_Hollowed_Reference_Layout.stl can also be used to print out all parts at once if your print bed is large enough - you will have to print a 2nd copy of the head as it needs to be printed twice to give you both parts needed - .

With download you'll get three Blender files, PosableHollowed_ColorCoded_LRUB.blend and PosableHollowed_ColorCoded_Position.blend are to help with assembly and PosableHollowed_Parts.blend is for those interested in modding or just curious how it's built.

This design was a pet project of mine, mostly to learn about printing joints but also something I used to brainstorm poses for my creative work.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Play

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

tested 0.1-0.2

Infill:

No infill should be nessesary

Notes:

As you might have noticed, there's only one half of the head, that's because it's identical on both sides, so just print it twice and you'll have all the parts.

The version in the pictures is printed in 0.2mm layer hight on a 0.4mm nozzle.
The print is designed to be able to be printed without any infill and support.
If you are experiencing problems with Left/Right arm_1 where the ball joint starts you might want to add some support or alternatively print multiple parts at once as with how small the parts are, if you don't have cooldown settings the nozzle might not allow the print to cool down between layers causing it to sag down.

Keep a lookout for warping, especially on the head as all parts need to be flat when glued together.

Got any questions, is something off in the files or just curious about something?
Post a comment or send me a message and I'd be happy to help out :)

Good to know for assembly.

Sandpapered off a tiny bit too much on a small part?
Super glue leaves a pretty thick, smooth and solid surface once dried.
So you might be able to salvage the part with a drop or two of super glue.
Most types of super glue goes matte once dried, use that to know when it's ok to see if the part fits better with the added thickness from the glue.

Part references:
With the download you'll get three Blender files, PosableHollowed_ColorCoded_LRUB.blend and PosableHollowed_ColorCoded_Position.blend are to help with assembly.
Turquoise = Right,
Red = Left,
Yellow = Top/Upper
Purple = Bottom/Lower
If a part is split in two, there can be a Top and a Bottom part.

Don't have Blender?
Don't worry, it's a free software that you can get over at https://www.blender.org
All you need to know to use the 3D references is that you use the middle click to spin the camera around, select an object with right click and that all the parts are listed in the panel to the right of the screen.

Joint assembly:
There are three different types of assembly needed for the joints.
Most joints just pop into place, like arms, neck and the ball joints connecting the legs to the pelvis. If you are experiencing a lot of resistance, give the ball joint a light rub down with sandpaper and try again. The joints on the Pelvis might need to be heated up slightly as well as the Thigh parts are quite thick.

The joints in the torso require that you glue the front and back or left and right side while around the ball joint, if glued together before you will not be able to get the ball joint into the socket.

The ankle and knee joints require some special attention as they use 1.75mm filament as rivets.
For those who are new to useing PLA as rivets,
Cannedmushrooms explains how to create PLA rivets pretty spot on: www.youtube.com/watch?v=WqNxYHWpYko

Grab a lighter, soldering iron or something very warm and about 100mm of 1.75mm filament. I can only recommend PLA as I have not had the chance to test other materials for this use.

Heat up the end of the filament (only about 3mm of the edge) and push it against a smooth surface. Next thread the filament through the joints you want to connect until the flat surface is flush against the joints. Cut off the other end so only about 3mm sticks out, heat it up and push it against a smooth to create the other end of the rivet.
This only needs to be done 4 times to connect the ankles and knees, and that's it! easy peasy.

Gluing parts together:
As with any surfaces that will be glued together, it will need to be lightly sandpapered down so that the surfaces will bond properly with the glue. For this print most super glues will work fine as there wont be any stretching going on.
As always, keep a fan on as fumes from super glue isn't the best to inhale.

description.text:
A clock that plots time. Designed with makeability in a fablab/makerspace/hackerspace in mind. You need:
  • Laser cutter or 3D printer
  • 1 Arduino
  • 3 servos
  • 1 dry wipe pen
  • M3 nuts, bolts, thread tap
    • Update to V1.01:
    added calibration routine and documentation to arduino code see the instruction tab above for building instructions http://wiki.fablab-nuernberg.de/w/Ding:Plotclock (german)
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iOLFP90DneY
    https://github.com/9a/plotclock (old, not maintained!) I'm not associated with any kits you are able to buy online

Update 08/15: You might want to take a look at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:931498/#instructions for a more detailed documentation Update 10/15: You should also check out http://www.instructables.com/id/Plot-Clock-for-dummies/?ALLSTEPS Thanks to Kjetil Egeland! Materials I used:
  • Arduino uno
  • Tower Pro 9g servos (those cheap ones from ebay)
  • WB SL DRYWIPE MARKER, bullet tip
  • A small custom servo adapter, there are shields or servo-arduinos that also can be used. You can also just use jumper wires: 5V to red servo wire, GND to brown or black servo wire and the arduino servopins connected to the yellow or orange servo wire
    • Building instructions:
    (for version 1.01!)

  • Lasercut plotclock_beta1.pdf from 3mm material or 3D print plotclock_SUP7.skp

    • the black areas in the pdf on the servo arms should be used to engrave some material away, so the servohorns settle in
    • use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:250204 for single STL files if you 3D print the clock (Thanks corben33!)

  • 3D print swee.stl or reuse some other cylindrical part for the sweeper

  • Tap 2.5mm holes with M3 thread

  • Assemble arms with M3 screws, gently adjust the counternuts so that the joints under the screw heads just have enough play for smooth movement (see joint picture).

  • load Arduino sketch plotclock_V1, see code comments for further information

    • http://playground.arduino.cc/Code/time library is needed

  • Add some sort of cloth with double sided tape to sweeper

  • Attach servos to digital pin 2, 3 and 4, according to arduino sketch, test them without anything attached by plugging in the arduino (the photos show it being connected to 1, 2 and 3, which isn't optimal since 1 is also the TX pin, so during arduino startup the lifting servo jumps around)

  • Put everything together

    • You may have to redrill the holes that are used for securing the servos, since some servo screws are a tight fit.
      Acrylic is brittle and easily breaks wen the mounting holes are to small. Only push the servo arms onto their hubs, don't secure them with screws! For initial calibration do not mount the resting clip for the wiper (danger of collision with the pen). Glue or screw the servo arms to the acrylic parts.

  • When attaching the servo arms, make sure they can turn enough to reach every point on the drawing surface by manually turning them

  • Power the arduino, it should start a calibration cycle where every second the position of both servos changes by rotating exactly 90 degrees (see last image in gallery)

  • Change the SERVOFAKTOR, SERVOLEFTNULL and SERVORIGHTNULL values until everything matches up (see code for more information)

  • Attach the pen and the sweeper holder only after testing everything else
    • This description is still a bit of a WIP, so comment if you have any questions!

comments.text:
the kinematics aren't that difficult, but you got to get your head around it once :) Best is to read backwards from servo2.writeMicroseconds(floor(((a2 + a1 - M_PI) * SERVOFAKTORLEFT) + SERVOLEFTNULL)); while looking at http://wiki.fablab-nuernberg.de/w/Datei:erklaerung.jpg
The return_angle functions only returns the cosine rule http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_cosines solved for angle a1
For the second arm the same procedure repeats but not with the pen as the endpoint, but the joint beneath the pen. For me the easiest way was to draw lots of triangles on paper and figure out how they interact ;)

comments.text: I believe the way the code works is that L1 is the length of the arms closer to the servo (center to center), L2 is the length between the center of the far side of the L1 linkage and the pen center, and L3 is half the distance between the servo axes. Your "L2 arms" have different lengths because the pen is 10mm from the end of the pivot point, but the geometry is what's important, and the pen is 55mm away.

And I would like to make it writes an alphabets (A,a,B,b,....) Please help me to figure out how to program to do.
If I want to make a bigger version to using same code parameters, can I just scale all parameters up, parts and code parameters ?
Please give some advises for me.
comments.author: pwoong

comments.text:
void number(...) draws the numbers with drawTo (for lines) and bogen (for arcs) functions:
Example for number 1:
drawTo(bx + 3 scale, by + 15 scale); // Move pen to point x:3 y:15 (left in the middle)
lift(0); // Move pen down to surface
drawTo(bx + 10 scale, by + 20 scale); // draw diagonally to x:10 y:20 (on the top right)
drawTo(bx + 10 scale, by + 0 scale); // draw straight down to y:0
// bx/by are the originpoints for this particular number on the printing surface, with scale you can make it bigger/smaller
Number 3 is just 2 bogen functions for the upper and lower arc.

comments.author: xenonion

comments.text:
use
bogenUZS(float bx, float by, float radius, int start, int ende, float sqee)
to draw clockwise arcs (or circles) bx/by = center, radius = radius, start = starting angle, ende = ending angle, squee = sqish or flatten circle
bogenGZS is the counter clockwise version

comments.text: To elaborate slightly, you can control the servo directly from the Arduino, up to the number of pins on the Arduino (12+, depending on the model), but the Arduino doesn't have enough power to drive very many servos, so you have to wire the control to the Arduino, and the power and ground lines to a power supply. For a few servos you can do this on a small breadboard, or solder everything directly. The board that is linked above does this, and adds a multiplexer, so you can control many more servo's.

The Most Awesome Glass Plate Holder Ever.

The bed dimensions are 230mm x 150mm and the clips will fit multiple makerbot dual clones or printers using the same bed configuration.

Post Process

title: Customized Bowden Extruder Mount With 1/8'' BSPT Thread

description.text:
I have decided to heavily edit the original Customizable Bowden Extruder | Mount for ANET A8 & Others as the thread was incompatible with the original E3D pushfits which use 1/8'' BSPT thread instead of standard M threads. So, I took Motorbase for 1/8" BSPT push fitting, Anet A8 ripped the thread out of it and merged it with the original bowden mount. Full list of changes:

  • Mount has been mirrored so it can be mounted on the left side of the frame.
  • The thread is designed to be a 1/8'' BSPT thread.
  • Customized for 1.75 mm filament using the original Anet A8 Nema17 motor and the original E3D hobbed gear.
  • The mount can now (and should) be printed sideways as in the STL. This makes for a better thread and holes for the filament. Use a lot of supports though.

As there was no mention of the screw that goes into the extruder, I found that the longest Allen screw that comes with the Anet A8 (and is usually part of the extruder cooling fan) works best if you use a nut and washer on top. See the image for better view. There is no need to overtighten it, as the original E3D hobbed gear is sharp as hell.

Rest of the assembly instructions can be found on the original thing, and are the same like for this one.

I have also included the Blender files in case you want to edit it further.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

40%

title: Murray Siemens generator interlock for 200A panel

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ewpvxFJEZjH

I used this for my generator Interlock setup on my SIEMENS 200 AMP electrical panel. It prevents turning on both the MAINS and the top-left double-breaker. This is commonly known as a backfeed generator interlock. The double-breaker on my panel goes to a generator hookup connection on the side of my house, for my portable Generator.

Printer:

MP Select Mini v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Be sure to fill in solid, for maximum strength. this may work better with metal, but the PLA i used seemed rigid enough to make everything feel secure.

I had minor warping due to size and flatness, but the screws corrected for it.

You can use #6-32 Computer case screws to hold the two parts together. An M4 may work as well, but i've not tested it.

two 10x32 flush mount screws are needed, with nuts and washers, to mount the back plate to the panel. Two holes must be drilled to allow for this, as well.

title: Filament spool holder for Geeetech Prusa i3

description.text:
This spool holder is almost vertical to minimize the constraints on the 3D printer frame.
As it use the white pipe delivered with the Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro B, it can hold 2 spools side by side. Filament samples will be also fit to this holder.
The various holes in the holder allow to block the filaments in order to recover them very quickly. You can also use these holes to stock your Allen wrenches or your gauge used to remove the plastic jam in the extruder.

You'll need 4 screws 3 x 12 mm to assemble the bottom with the top parts of the right and left supports.

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro B

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Make sure that the front side of each arm is facing the heat bed in order to have a nice aspect on front of you when it is installed on your printer.

comments.text: Nice design....but, the logic behind the position and height can create a problem.  Each time the extruder pulls/tugs on the filament, especially when the filament might be tucked within another line of filament, the pulling/tugging can create the entire framework to vibrate, which might cause the print to be mis-aligned.  Off-frame filament holder does not create such a pull/tug and won't screw up the print.
comments.author: DDD_guy

comments.text:
You are fully right DD_Guy. In theory this can cause vibration in the frame, nevertheless the Prusa i3 frame is strong and stable (8 mm of acrylic frame). The cantilevered is only 3 cm between the frame and the spool center. I've printed various things with this spool holder and I can tell you that there is no visible vibration in the frame (the short and quick heat bed movements generate much more vibration). The spool unwinds smoothly and evenly. Moreover the filament simply "fall" directly in the extruder, there is no angle at all.
Ideally a shelf on top of the 3D printer would be safer, but if you don't have this possibility, a spool support on to on the printer works good.
Thanks for you comment on this, it helps the community.

title: LipoGuard: TPU battery protector with slot for DroneKeeper Mini and 25° angle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This LiPo battery protector for bottom mounted batteries helps protect them while giving you a slot to store your DroneKeeper Mini. Also, it acts as a stand to take off at an angle of 25 degrees. The design is largely inspired by skullndrones's design and has influences from a design by 2mafpv (which is horrible to print, needs supports and is quite messy when printed with TPU due to stringing etc., not to mention it takes ages to print).

This version is faster to print and doesn't require supports. All overhanging sections can be printed as bridges and so if you control the flow and cooling right, you won't need any supports. Print with TPU for optimal results and to hold the DroneKeeper Mini snuggly.

The design weighs 11.25g, when printed with the parameters as described below.

title: Dream-flight AHI servo tray for TGY-D56MG 5.6g digital MG HV cheap servo

description.text:
This servo tray allows you to mount cheap, 1.2KG powerful and precise TGY-D56MG servos in the Dream-flight AHI to save weight and use 2 lipo direct supply.
Extreme Caution: Turnigy says those servos are 7.4v capable but I found max voltage you can feed it is 8.0V, if you feed with more of that voltage you will burn it...
the simple solution I found to direct supply with 2 lipo is to put a cheap 1n4001 or similar diode in series of battery, this make the voltage drop 0.5 to 0.7V and all work perfectly.
if you use a frsky telemetry receiver you can adjust the offset voltage in telemetry screen and obtain the the correct battery voltage read...
have fun!

Here the servo: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigytm-tgy-d56mg-coreless-ds-mg-hv-servo-1-2kg-0-10sec-5-6g.html?___store=en_us

description.text:
Spirited Away is one of my Favourite Movies,
The Feeling stirred up in this Movie are nothing but breathtaking.

Losing yourself or the feeling of losing your Identity not knowing what path to follow.
The Love you feel for your family and bumping into a friend after many years without contact.

Spirited Away has these and more.
It is one of the most well-known movies to come out of the Brain of Hayao Miyazaki

http://spiritedaway.wikia.com/wiki/Spirited_Away_Wiki

No-Face is a Lonely Spirit that the Hero, a Young Girl called Chihiro lets into the BathHouse because he looks sad alone in the Rain.

http://spiritedaway.wikia.com/wiki/No-Face_(Kaonashi)

This one has been a long time coming, A Sculpt I have been reluctant to release because it has been a personal journey for myself.

author: chopcat

description.text:
This is about a 12-piece dissection of a hexagram. Starting from a regular hexagon, one can construct a hexagram by connecting the diagonals and further dissect the hexagram into 12 pieces as shown. The hexagram, so dissected, can be reassembled into 3 congruent small hexagrams.

This dissection can be a great project for K-12 students and teachers to learn about 3D design ideas. For better effect, the inner parts are 5mm in thickness; the outer pieces are 3mm high. The whole star has a radius of 60mm. Have fun!

Reference

Frederickson, G. N. (1997). Dissections: Plane & fancy. Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press.

This is a gear from a book by Patrick Rothfuss called "The Slow Regard of Silent Things"... It is broken and brazen and perfect and true. It is entirely scintillant and sweet and will not tarnish. I originally created this for my Tronxy X3 to mount the spool on the lower frame inline with the extruder.

It is also a baby-monitor, with the camera and microphone I can see and hear our baby.

remixed_from.author: Tamadite
remixed_from.title: Rear BLTouch holder for Geeetech I3

description.text:
NOTE: I have depreciated this model in favour of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2667913.

One of the drawbacks of the original design is that it hits the frame of the printer and so it is necessary to extend the X end-stop to avoid printhead collisions with the frame; a consequence of this is a reduced print area, around 0.5cm.
I reworked the design to avoid this problem as well as to make it thiner and lighter: from 13.47g to 9.52g (around 30% lighter).

In order to meet the assembling recommendations, I suggest printing out a draft design, mount it on the printhead, mount the BLTouch and then measure the distance between the base of the BLTouch (not the pin but the plastic base) and the tip of the nozzle. The base of the BLTouch should be 8.3mm (+/-0.2mm) above the tip of the nozzle. I have found that to measure the distance between the two it is better to do it with the printer display —the Z height displayed is in mm, and by looking at the difference between the two. The procedure could be: take an object, placed on the bed and move the Z-axis until the nozzle barely touches the object. Take note of the Z position. Relocate the object so it only meets the BLTouch on its plastic base (not the pin). Adjust the Z-axis until the BLTouch plastic base barely touches the object. Take note of the new Z position. Performing the corresponding subtraction of the two values gives you the distance between the tip of the nozzle and the plastic base of the BLTouch. Do the necessary maths to determine how short or long the draft BLTouch is for your printer. Contact me with the new dimension and off you go with your tailored BLTouch holder!

See the 2D drawing for more details.

title: Da Vinci bed rail mount

description.text:
I created this due to the bed bushings going bad on my Da Vinci 1.0A. The rods are 10mm and machined down to 8mm on the ends to fit the factory mount. I don't believe these are hardened rods. As far as I'm aware of they used this same mount for the bed rods on all of the bigger printers.

The machining down to 8mm on the ends make them hard to replace. I made this almost exact other than having the inside diameter of 10mm on my mount but then I wanted to include a m3 nut for the upper mount so the holes are not exactly in the center but everything fits good.

I made mine in PETG at a higher infill % but again infill is up to you.

The white one in the picture is the factory mount for comparison.

description.text: This is a tool for the billiards variation Cut-throat. The rules allow players to claim a series of balls, one of which being either a multiple of three, or a multiple of five, depending on the number of players. This design is for a box which allows a player to indicate which ball they've claimed, and which is a storage box for the markers.

Notes:

The model was designed to be printed without supports - there is an overhang so that the box lid can stack on the bottom of the box when open - the bevel on the overhang should be at a small enough angle to print successfully without supports.

The pool balls (marker pieces) were designed to be printed as pairs and glued together. They are modified hemispheres. The flare corrects distortion difference which seems to occur between the solid bottom layers and the hollow upper layers. This should produce roughly spherical balls as a result.

They are separate so that they can be printed in different colors, or combinations of colors.

My first and only print of the box was printed with ColorFabb nGen filament, and required minimal finishing.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

title: Pulley block (soft mount) for 7-8mm OD rope

description.text:
This pulley is durable and fail safe due to the soft mount mechanism. It uses a 608 skateboard bearing to ensure smooth operation. The printed parts are simply there to guide the rope through and around the bearing, so the pulley is not reliant on the strength of the printed parts.

Use a vice to press the 608 bearing into the bearing rope trace.
Place two M8 washers on either side of the bearing and slide it into the pulley block. insert the rope through the pulley block, the washers and the 608 bearing as seen in the photo's.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

90%

Notes:

Orient the Pulley block on it's side and it will require no support and print the layers in the strong direction. (not on its top as the stl is oriented).
Note the rope trace has a 0.5mm ridge on one side so the 608 only goes in from one side and butt's up.

I used PLA because of its rigidity and the need for 90% infill which would cause ABS or nylon to warp a lot.

author: GrandeJefe

description.text: Stabilizes the chassis of Prusa printer on a base plate. I used an 18 mm thick chipboard, the bolts are M5x35. The nuts M5 under the plate are of self-locking type due to permanent vibrations. For the Original Prusa printer, are 10 mm brackets, for Chinese copies such as Anet are 8 mm (I have a similar printer as Anet, maybe it will be useful). Files I labeled "middle" I used for my printers. Files with a +/- sign have a modified height. The nut cases help tighten bolts more easily, the nuts are recommended to be glued with a CA glue - it will be easier to assemble. Instead of legs, I used 4 kitchen sponges under the plate, which prevent vibration transfer to the table.

I wanted a very fast, basic, mount for my Raspberry Pi 3. While there are lots of great cases and enclosures on Thingiverse already, I was really excited about getting my Pi in place and playing with it.
After a bit of design; this is what I came up with. Quick, dirty, and basic... but it works great and can be printed in less than half an hour!

There are two sets of mounting holes: one to secure the bracket to its new home (I mounted mine upside-down) and another set to secure the Pi to the bracket.

The first set of holes is countersunk at 82 degrees to accommodate wood screws, the second set is for small machine screws. I'm not sure what I used, as I just had them laying around from an old television teardown. I think the outside diameter of the threads was 2.5 mm or so. If you'd like better dimensions, just post a comment and I'll go make some better measurements.

This was made for a Pi 3, but should also work just fine for a Pi 2 as well.

When mounted, I realized that the overall height of the device could be dropped a bit (maybe another .200"??). If you observe the same thing and it bugs you enough that you'd like a change, let me know and I'll edit/repost the .stl file.

Hope this is handy for you!

remixed_from.title: (v2) The Clothespin Pocket Pistol "3d printed!" V2

title: (v2.5) The Clothespin Pocket Pistol "3d printed!" V2.5 Bolt Action

description.text:
This is version 2.5 of "The Clothespin Pocket Pistol" Update:
Added a new bolt part.
Now possible to reload/tension spring from the back. New features:
New diameter of barrel (5mm).
.177 caliber (4.5mm) ammo will fit.
Bolt action system, no more jamming.
Easy one movement loading, spring will lock by itself.
Built in support, no need for slicer support.
Now you can pretty much shoot anything that fits the barrel. Disadvantages:
It`s still simple to print but this version features small parts and even more overhang so you might need to look over your printer settings.
You need to clean out the support and other obstacles so the
bolt can move freely.
Smaller ammo (toothpicks) might get stuck.
The bolt part might need to be replaced after a while. All credits still goes to:
Source: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vC2BSb9MZYc
Source: http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-Make-a-Clothespin-Gun/ Also thanks to Jaidyn Edwards for reviewing my design
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N8kuE_cFl2k This Thing is a work-in-progress and there is room for improvement :D I will add this bolt action system to the v2 with 4mm barrel when i have time. Play safe and don`t shoot in yours or others eyes !!!!!!

I printed all parts at the same time. I scaled up the pistol 4% due to ABS shrinking Bolt printed horizontal, no scaling
Do notice that one side of bolt is different. End plug printed vertically, no scaling
Best is to print 2 of these at the same time so the plastic on each part have time to cool down. 0.20mm layer height
5 shells for strength
15% infill

title: Adjustable Axis m1013 camera mount: Simpl3 Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Version 3.4d is here! There are many improvements.
an instructional video can be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mlLpRXXYdv0
Please note this video was made with a prepackaged product in mind. Adjustable "Axis" camera mount. The Axis camera is one of the webcams used in FRC. The mount that comes with the camera doesn't tighten enough so I designed and printed this for my team (3840).

****these instructions are for version 1****
For instructions on version 3.4d go here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mlLpRXXYdv0
All vitamins can be purchased wholesale at Fastenall.
printed parts: 1x camera mount top
1x camera mount middle
1x camera mount bottom
vitamins: 4x flat head #6 mounting screws of your choice (depends on what you are mounting to)
2x #6 nut
1x #8 nut
1x #6 x 3/4" machine screw
1x #6 x 2.5" (3" will work to) Machine screw
1x #8 x 3/4" machine screw (I think #8 is what I used here but I just designed around what I had) 1) Drink Root Beer.
2) Print 1 of each file. "camera mount middle" and "camera mount bottom" both require support material. I would suggest the latest version of slic3r as you can use support on some parts but not others in the same job. MakerWare can probably do this too but I have never used MakerWare so I don't know. Use <=.3mm layer height.
3) Drink more ROOT Beer.
4) Remove support material
5) make a hole behind the base for the adjustment screw to go through
6) Mount base onto a surface with the flat top screws (don't forget to put the #6 nut in the trap on the bottom!)
7) Connect middle with top using the #6 x 2.5" screw
8) Connect middle/top assembly to base
9) Glue the camera into the mount (I would suggest hot glue)
10) DRINK MORE ROOT BEER (optional)

title: Rollei QAL-40 Camera Mounting Plate (C4i, C5i, C40i, C50i, Compact Traveler No 1, Compact Traveler No 10, CT-4A, CT-5A, CT-5C, M5 Mini, PGA-584, PGA-484, TT-1, T2S)

description.text:
I needed another mounting plate for my Rollei Compact Traveler No. 1 tripod and measured the dimensions and hacked it into Fusion360. The Model also includes the 1/4" thread for the camera mounting screw.

I use this screw (the short one) for this plate: http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/AEybE2B
It is a few mm longer than the stock screw of the plate, but it works with my equipment.

Please don't use the printed plate with heavy gear. I will use it only for action cams, flashes and mobile recorder. I tested the plate successfully with an EOS 70D + Canon 60mm macro lens + Flash (about 2kg).

How to support me?

Do you like my things and do you want to support me? You can use these links if you want to buy something. This helps me doing more things. Thanks!

Banggood: https://goo.gl/ZXgx3A

Printed in Monoprice PLA+ Blue & White.

Assembly order:
Place a 'spacer' all the way forward inside the 'front'
Push the 'insert' up against the spacer.
Add another 'Spacer' behind the 'insert' to lock it in place.
Put a string of USB 5V LED lights around the inside.
Snap the back on.
Enjoy!

title: Floppy Disk
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In the not so distabced past there used to be floppy disks and corresponding drivers on computers for the disks.
These were used for transferring files between machines long before the internet, CD's and USB thumb drivers were invented or became widely used.
The floppy disks had a capacity of around 1.4MB of data and often were also refered as 1 inch disks.
Even though they are no longer in use for the latest computers, many machines still have support both in hardware level (connections on the motherboard) and on software level (BIOS and OS).
This model is made of two parts and is good for dual color printing.

Atom 2.5 EX

Designing

Fusion 360 was the cad software I chose to use when designing these coins. I started off with an image of a generic poker coin that was downloaded of the internet, then i researched the normal size for a coin to be.

This gave me the dimensions I needed to start designing. First I started with the outline and the nuggets on the outer shell. Then I traced the dice numbers, all to 1.5mm diameter. This gave me the bones of a genuine Poker Coin.

After I added some finishing touches, such as the rectangles revolving in a circular pattern near the centre of the coin. Then finally, I added the 100 in the middle, and extruded as a new body so I could still print it in dual extrusion.

This file is printed on the Prusa i3 mk2 with the multi material upgrade.

description.text:
Update!
Added another bracket for the newer power adapter. I have not tested it myself, it is modeled after dimensions provided by jakebullet70.

After some time I found the X1’s habit to spread out all over the place a bit frustrating and decided to do something about it. This something should be simple and reasonably fast to print. The result is presented here and is in no way a beauty but it will do the work.
The print is a bit tricky as it use almost all the X1’s print area and you have to place the clips in the right spots (see PDF drawing).  For the assembly you will need 4 M3x20, 4 M3 nuts and 2 T-nuts with 12mm bolts.
The center of gravity gets a bit high for the footprint, so I suggests you attach it to a board or plate of some sort, a tray maybe.
Cheers!

title: CL-260 AC Block C14 + Switch mount for 2020 Misumi profile

description.text:
This is a AC C14 socket & rocker switch mount designed for my CL-260 printer but works on any 2020 Extrusion Profile aswell.
I had an old and broken ATX PSU which delivered me the C14 socket and the rocker switch...

The port for the C14 socket is 19mm x 27,5mm
and the port for the rocker switch is 12,30mm x 19mm.

Mounting holes for the back cover and the 2020 Profile are for M3 screws as well as for the C14 socket. The holes for the Socket and back cover are designed to self thread.

If you liked it please share a picture of your make.
